III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth D may have been exposed to ringworm and did not receive
needed timely medical attention for an ongoing cough.
Investigation This investigation was assigned to me on 3/27/24.
Interviews:
I contacted Complainant via email. She had no additional
licensing concerns relative to Wolverine Center.
I contacted Youth D’s Foster Care Worker and notified her of the
DCWL investigation assignment. She expressed no additional
licensing concerns.
I interviewed Youth D, age 17 years, 11 months, jointly with
Government Worker 1 on 3/28/24. He appeared drowsy,
displayed disorganized speech, and mumbled his words. Youth D
was admitted to the facility’s short-term shelter on 3/1/24.
According to MISACWIS, this is his first out-of-home placement. I
observed a hospital band on his wrist.
Since his admission to Wolverine Center, Youth D said he has
been to the hospital emergency room several times for various
reasons. At one point during the interview, his thoughts fixated on
someone at the hospital “poking and scratching” him in his head
with needles. Youth D was unable to explain what this meant. He
was also unable to recall the concerns he expressed to
Complainant that triggered this investigation. He said he is not
sure if he is currently sick, but denied having a cold, cough, or
ringworm. “I did go to the hospital after making the complaint…I
have had a chance to speak to the nurse here…I sleep a lot.”
Asked if he has been mistreated at the facility, Youth D
responded, “I don’t know. I don’t get in trouble here. I don’t pay
2

attention.” Asked if he feels safe at the facility, he nodded
affirmatively.
I interviewed Therapist jointly with Government Worker 1. He said
he met with Youth D during his first week at the facility and Youth
D did not have a severe cough at that time. Therapist has
however observed Youth D with sleep problems, delusions,
auditory hallucinations, responding verbally to internal stimuli, and
showing signs of schizophrenia. Therapist said Youth D will no
longer be considered for independent living due to a recent “failed”
independent living interview with Complainant. Youth D’s new
discharge plan is adult foster care.
Medical documents reviewed:
Discharge paperwork - Children’s Hospital 3/1/24 – Normal
physical
Discharge paperwork - Beaumont Hospital 3/11/24 – Acute
pharyngitis.
A physician-signed well-child examination dated 3/13/24
Discharge paperwork - Beaumont Hospital 3/18/24 – Psychogenic
paranoid psychosis
Telepsychiatry Interview 3/20/24 – No medications prescribed.
Discharge paperwork - Beaumont Hospital 3/23/24 – Chest pain
Discharge paperwork Children’s Hospital 3/26/24 – Chest wall
pain
Government Worker had no findings.
Analysis There is no evidence Youth D had or has ringworm and no
evidence he did not receive timely routine or emergency medical
care as needed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Title qualifications
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Unidentified staff allegedly gave Youth D a hat known to be
infected with ringworm spores.
3

Investigation Interviews:
Youth D denied having ringworm or that any staff at the facility
gave him a hat infected with ringworm. Rather he said an
unidentified youth at the facility teased him that he had given or
would give him ringworm. Youth D could not identify the youth
who teased him about this.
In terms of Youth D telling Complainant that a staff gave him a hat
infected with ringworm, Therapist indicated “that is definitely part
of Youth D’s delusion. There’s no basis in reality on that.”
Analysis Youth D denied the allegations made by Complainant against an
unidentified staff were true.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Unidentified staff allegedly gave Youth D's medication to an
unidentified person.
Investigation Interviews:
On 3/28/24 Youth D said he did not know if he is currently
prescribed medication. He said he heard unidentified youth or
staff say an unknown person flushed his medication down the
toilet. Youth D did not know when he heard this or who said it. “I
heard somebody gave my meds from the hospital to someone
else.”
Therapist stated that hearing that someone took his medications
and flushed them is also part of his Youth D’s delusional thought
process.
Document reviewed:
Youth D’s March 2024 medication log indicates he was prescribed
an antibiotic for 7 days from 3/14 – 3/20 and Ibuprofen for 3 days
from 3/26 – 3/28. Youth D refused two doses and was not offered
4

one dose of the antibiotic because he was away at the hospital.
He refused all doses of the Ibuprofen prescribed.
Government Worker had no findings.
Analysis The MAR indicates Youth D was offered an antibiotic and
Ibuprofen and either ingested or refused it. There is no evidence
these medications went missing, were taken by or given to
another person or flushed down the toilet.
CONSULTATION
On 4/1/24 I recommended to Youth D’s Foster Care Worker that
she arrange for him to have a comprehensive psychological or
psychiatric evaluation to determine his needs for psychotropic
medication and a treatment plan at the shelter as well as plan for
an appropriate next placement as he will turn age 18 on 5/1/24.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
